Award.AwardTitle: SHINE: The Anatomy of Coronal Mass Ejections
Award.AbstractNarration: This three-year SHINE project aims to explore the origin and evolution of coronal mass ejections (CMEs) by determining the basic anatomical correspondence between transient structure observed in-situ and the source structures that give rise to CMEs in the solar corona. Following data analysis, the project team will study the onset of CMEs and their evolution through the heliosphere out to 1 AU and beyond, where the team will analyze the CME components in detail with in-situ spacecraft. The PI and Co-I will use two models to reconstruct the CME: simple (TH) and sophisticated (ENLIL). The project will also involve processing and analyzing data from the STEREO, SDO, SOHO, ACE, and Wind missions. Recent breakthroughs in STEREO data processing by the project team have enabled the measurement of solar wind transient structures (e.g., CMEs) in unprecedented detail. During this project, the team will perform case studies of CME events using the latest datasets, and a statistical analysis of older datasets. The broader impacts of the work are twofold: (1) education and training of students via international collaborations and an existing REU program; and (2) publication of data products on online databases, publication of project results in scientific and technical journals, and scientific presentations at conferences and workshops. The research agenda of this project supports the Strategic Goals of the AGS Division in discovery, learning, diversity, and interdisciplinary research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Anatomy of Coronal Mass Ejections

Coronal mass ejections (CMEs) are large eruptions of magnetic field and plasma from the Sun. Carrying over 1012 kg of mass and reaching speeds of several hundred kilometers per second, they are the largest singular eruptions from the Sun. CMEs can severely disrupt the Earth’s magnetic field, causing severe space weather and damaging power stations, spacecraft and increasing radiation dosages for astronauts and airline passengers. Understanding these solar phenomena is a major objective of the NSF space physics program, both from a scientific perspective and because it is in our technological interests to predict their arrival at the Earth and the damage they are likely to cause upon impact.

 

CMEs are best observed using coronagraphs, that block out the bright solar photosphere revealing the faint surrounding corona. They are difficult to see even in the corona, but with the utility of coronagraphs on board spacecraft (such as those on SOHO and STEREO) and the application of background removal techniques, we now see them routinely. A “classic” CME (figure 1) looks like a light bulb with three distinct parts: a leading edge (thought to consist of coronal material accumulated ahead of a driving magnetic flux rope) followed by a cavity (thought to be the driving flux rope) followed by a bright core (thought to be a solar prominence). Despite intensive study of CMEs for over 40 years we still know relatively little about the nature of their launch and evolution, particularly when they are far from the Sun. This is because of a scarcity of observational data that inhibits our ability to verify the many mathematical models that have been developed to describe their launch from the solar corona and evolution through the solar wind.

 

The goal of this three-year project, which was funded by the NSF SHINE program, was to observationally dissect the CME and assess the development of its components, from their pre-launch magnetic properties, the causes for the launch and departure from the Sun, and their behavior as they evolved through the corona and the solar wind. This has been made possible in recent years with the development of sophisticated analytical tools for coronagraphs and with the utility of a wide field solar wind imager, called a heliospheric imager. They work on similar physics to coronagraphs, and have emerged as a new field in the last 10 years. Such instruments can track CMEs continuously from the Sun, but require complex analysis to extract information about them. These, combined with the stereoscopic viewpoints from the STEREO spacecraft and high-cadence, high-resolution images from the SDO spacecraft, enable the measurement of CME anatomy with unprecedented precision. For the first time, we can see the launch and evolution of each component of CMEs, and our findings challenge some views on CMEs that have been held by scientists for decades.

 

The project produced the following results:

(1) An observational narrative describing the onset, launch, and 3-D evolution of a CME (figure 2). We found that it required three separate onset mechanisms and a possible bisection to completely remove the CME flux rope from the Sun, and described how its evolution affected its appearance in imagers and when it arrived at in-situ spacecraft a distances around 1 AU from the Sun.

(2) The first ever continuous measurements of a CME-associated prominence out to distances near 1 AU. We found that the prominence ionizes as it traverses through the solar corona and that its mass decreased rapidly as it evolved through the solar wind.

(3) Measurements of the density and magnetic field of the CME when it was near the Sun, combining coronagraph measurements with those from a distant pulsar that the CME passed in front of.

(4) We found evidence to challenge two views about CMEs that have been accepted by the community. The first was that some CMEs are actually blast waves driven by a localized impulsive energy release, and not driven by a magnetic flux rope. The second is that the bright core component, which has for decades been believed to be prominence material, is not a prominence at all, but rather an optical illusion caused by the geometry of a twisted flux rope.

(5) Measurements of the background solar wind through which all CMEs propagate. We measured the properties of the turbulence there and the tendency of solar wind domain boundaries to resist turbulent breakup.

 

Broader Impacts: Our project provided education and training to the next generation of scientists, enhanced international collaboration through joint studies with European colleagues, and allowed for multidisciplinary cooperation with a joint project between solar physics and radio astronomy groups. Our results were disseminated via a multitude of publications, including 12 peer-reviewed journal articles, 20 conference presentations, and 4 invited seminars.
